div.head: ❧ To the gentle and godly affected Reader.
div.p:
ALthough I am not ignoraūt, how daūgerous an enterprise it is, in this age eyther to write or diuulgate any worke abrode (most gentle reader) yet I would not willingly commit that inconstant leuitie, or light inconstancy should be obiected agaynste me, for not impartyng vnto thee these my simple Prelections, and speciallye for not the accomplishyng of my promise, whiche I openly made to an open auditorie, partely also to staye the great importunitie of certayne of my friendes, who hath at diuerse and sondry tymes expostulate with me, for deferyng of the same so longe a tyme. Beholde nowe they come fourth, althoughe late, yet (I truste) not to late. And althoughe they be more grosse and rude, then meete to satisfie and aunswere the fine heades of this tyme, yet coumpt them, I pray thee, not all vaine and vnprofitable. And know thou that it is a godly thing, not onely to set fourth such worthy workes, as tende to gods glory & the vtility of the publique weale, namely to the instructiō of the simple and ignoraunt, but also to haue onely a good will to do the same.2. Cor. 8, For where habilitie lacketh, good will is onely to be receaued, & not reiected, as the holy Apostle saint Paule wtiteth to the Corinthians. Si voluntas prompta est secundū id quod habet accepta est, non secundum id quod non habet: If there he a willing minde, it is accepted according to that a mā hath, and not according to that he hath not: And looke not here (gētle reader) for an exquisite methode, looke not here for the flourishyng flowers of Demosthenes, looke not here for the eloquent stile of Cicero, for that veine of writing, to this kinde of argument is vtterly impertinent, but thou shalte haue here certaine lessons, although playne, yet not al vaine although not beautified with great learning, yet profitable for thy readyng. If my rashe remeritie or temerous rashnes shall offend any person, let him remēber the greke cōmon prouerbe, which doth promise 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , that is pardō to him, whiche geueth fourth his first attemptate, and experiment, wherfore if thou wilt vouchafe to read them, when thou art at leasure, and (as they say) horis successiuis, I shall thincke my laboure well bestowed, and that I haue not lost omnino oleum & operam If these simple Prelections chaunce peraduenture to come into the handes of some scrupulous and captious criticall reader (for whose disease there is no medicine) let him know that it is a great deale more easie to carpe other mens doinges, then to giue better of his owne. Agayne on the other side, if there be any of Momus clients which will vmbraide me for inserting and putting in other mennes sayinges and sentences in this my vnframed frame, let him consider these foure thynges following. First let him weigh I say what was in the like case obiected to saint Hierome, writing his learned Commentaries vpon the Prophets, for he in the preface of the second booke vpon the Prophet Micheas, writeth after this maner. Where they say, that I robbe the volumes and workes of Origine, and that it becometh not the writings of the auncient fathers to be contaminate and spoyled, that thing whiche they esteme and coumpte to be a vehement and reprochefull checke, I do coumpte it to be no smale prayse, for as much as I followe hym, with whom I doubt not both you and all wise men are much pleased. For if it be so haynous a faulte to translate the good sayinges and sentences of the Grecians, then let Ennius, and Virgill, Plautus, and Cecilius, Terentius, and Tullius and other eloquent and learned men be accused and blamed, who haue not onely translated certayne verses, but also whole Chapiters, long bookes, and whole Comedies, yea thē let our brother Hilarius be gilty and accused of theft, because writing vpon the Psalmes, he hath translated and turned almost forty thousand verses out of the foresaid Origene, and set them into his owne booke. All whose negligence I wish rather to follow,Eccle. 1. then their obscure and darke diligence. Haec Hieronimus. Secōdly let him remember not onely that whiche Salomon recordeth in his boke called Ecclesiastes. Quid est quod fuit? ipsum quod futurum est. Quid est quod factum este ipsum quod faciendū est. What is that hath bene? that which shalbe, & what is that, that hath ben done? that which shalbe done. But let him also I say expende this which Terence writeth, Nullum est iam dictum, quod non dictum sit prius, there is nothing now spoken, that hath not bene spoken before. Thirdly let him marcke the title of the booke named Pragmatei • or Miscellanea Whiche entreateth
of diuerse & sondry things, and therfore nedeth the more mens iudgemēts & helpes, Fourthly and finally let him ponder and weigh how I haue eased the reader of a great deale of labour and payne, to the attaynement of the knowledge of such thinges whiche he should otherwise bene faine to haue sought in diuerse and sondry workes, and those huge and great. Here I haue collected and couched the same together in this one litle opuscle & small worke, whiche also may saue him from disbursing of some parte of his money, in deare biyng other great workes. If he expend and consider (I say) these things, I trust he will ceasse from faulte finding, and be more willing to be thankefull. What should I say more? If any wilbe so open eyed, and such faulte finders, that they will despise these my poore mites, which I caste with the poore widowe into the treasurie chest of Christes Churche, I would friendly desire suche with the wordes of Horace.

l.hi: Si quid nouisti rectius istis, candidus imparti, si non, his vtere mecum.

q.l: If better thing you can write or saye,
Gently imparte them, I do you praye:
If not, these thinges with me do you vse,
As you would not that I yours should refuse.

div.p: What profit is it for any man to hide his talent in a napken: and with the vnprofitable seruaunt to be cast into vtter darkenes? The sonne of Sirach sayth,Eccle. 20. Sapientiae reconditae & thesauri abstrusi nuilam esse vtilitatem.

q.l: Of wisedome shut vp there is no pleasure,
Nor profite commeth of hidden treasure.

div.p: Lucianus also writeth. Occultae Musices nullum esse respectum.

q.l: Of hidden Musicke there is no respecte,
Continuall silence who doth not neglecte?

div.p: By which aucthorities I am moued to geue fourth the litle talent of my knowledge, where with God hath endewed me, whiche if you shall take gently and in good parte, you shall animate, encite, and sturre me forwarde to publish other things that shalbe I trust, both profitable and pleasaunt vnto you, I do not meane to such as hath made great progresse in deepe and profounde learning, but vnto such as be yet arriuing toward the porte of good Literature, of whiche nomber I coumpte my selfe to be one, or rather one who hath tasted of good learning onely. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 .

div.head: Lucian.
div.p: This Lucian by a surrename, was called a blasphemer an Atheos, that is without God, he wrote workes in Greeke to the nomber of .171. he lyued vnder Traian the Emperour, and beyng torne of dogges, dyed miserablye.
